newsitem.title: GERMANY: Daimler to decide restructuring in early 97.
newsitem.headline: Daimler to decide restructuring in early 97.

text.p: German industrial group Daimler-Benz AG plans to decide on a massive restructuring plan at a supervisory board meeting in early 1997, the company said on Tuesday.
"The board wants to consider the management structure more intensively over the next few weeks," Daimler said.
Daimler-Benz, Germany's largest industrial company, has been considering a reorganisation for some months as part of its efforts to make individual operating units more profitable.

The reorganisation has caused turmoil within the Daimler group. According to local media, Mercedes-Benz AG chairman Helmut Werner had threatened to resign if his car and truck unit were more closely integrated in the new structure.

Industry sources said on Monday that Daimler chairman Juergen Schrempp had gone as far as to offer Werner the post of chairman of a restructured Daimler in order to keep the Mercedes chief within the group.
"Everybody wants to keep Werner in the company," one source said on Monday.
Werner's contract as management board member of Daimler, which expires at the end of 1997, is up for renewal at a supervisory board meeting on November 6. His contract at Mercedes runs until 1999.
But Daimler said on Tuesday that it would not decide any personnel moves on November 6.
According to newspaper reports over the weekend, Schrempp planed to integrate Mercedes with the parent company as part of his plans to return Daimler to its transportation roots.

Mercedes, which now makes up around three-quarters of Daimler's group revenues, has predicted its 1996 profits will be "clearly" higher than last year's 2.275 billion marks ($1.5 billion) profit. ($ = 1.533 German Marks)
